(CBS) QUOTE OF THE 
      DAY “You don't stop laughing because you grow old. You 
      grow old because you stop laughing.” - Michael Pritchard 




TODAY’S TRIVIA A Sphygmomanometer measures blood 
      pressure. 



TONIGHT ON THE CBS 
      EVENING NEWS Here's an early look 
      at what we are working on for tonight's broadcast of the CBS EVENING NEWS 
      from Anchor and Managing Editor, Katie Couric Hi everyone, 
      If there isn’t significant improvement on the ground in Iraq, the 
      president won’t be able to hold onto some of his key Republican support in 
      Congress. That’s the message moderate Republicans had for President Bush 
      after they pulled him into a private meeting for what has been called a 
      “very frank” discussion earlier this week. Our chief White House 
      correspondent, Jim Axelrod, will provide details about that 
      meeting. Sharyl Attkisson will report from Capitol Hill on how 
      Congress and President Bush may now be working toward a compromise on the 
      crucial issue of setting benchmarks for progress in Iraq. The 
      maker of OxyContin and three of its current and former executives pleaded 
      guilty today to misleading the public about how addictive the powerful 
      drug can be. A U.S. Attorney said the company unleashed an easily abused 
      drug on an “unsuspecting and unknowing public.” The company has agreed to 
      pay hundreds of millions of dollars. Correspondent Bob Orr will 
      have the story. Two forces of nature are clashing in the southeast 
      as massive wildfires continue to torch the Florida-Georgia border. Not far 
      away, the first named storm of the year has brought a sprinkling of rain 
      to help firefighters there, but tinderbox conditions elsewhere in the 
      country are contributing to new fires. Kelly Cobiella will report. 
      It might be heating up all along the East Coast – for good – if a 
      new NASA report is right. Randall Pinkston will share the 
      disturbing report about just how hot our planet could get before the turn 
      of the century. Elizabeth Palmer will report from London on 
      the news today that one of America’s best friends, British Prime Minister 
      Tony Blair, is stepping down. We’ll look back at his decade in office. 
      To cap our broadcast, Kelly Wallace will have an Eye 
      on the American Family report. She’ll take a 
      look at the phenomenon called “opting out.” It’s the idea that 
      high-powered career moms are deciding to stay at home with their kids 
      rather than work full-time. But now some experts are saying when women 
      stop working, it may not be voluntary. Thanks! Katie
For more on two of the stories noted above, please click on the

      EVENING NEWS On this week's Assignment America. The senior senior. 
      She's the oldest graduating senior in her CLASS .. maybe even in HISTORY. 
      An inspirational reminder that .. It's NEVER too late...plus a lot more, 
      that's Friday night on the CBS Evening News. If you would like 
      more information on any of these stories or the broadcast, please click on 
      the following address and e-mail us: evening@cbsnews.com 
      



TONIGHT ON DAVID LETTERMAN Join Dave tonight on 
      The Late Show with self-help guru Dr. 
      Phil AND animal expert Jack Hanna! 



FRIDAY MORNING ON THE EARLY SHOW Harry Smith, 
      Hannah Storm, Julie Chen and Chris Wragge, of our New 
      York affiliate, WCBS, anchor THE EARLY SHOW from New York. Dave Price will bring us the weather. 
      Russ Mitchell will join us live from Jamestown, VA. 
      Along with the top news of the day, we will also have the 
      following stories: 48 HOURS MYSTERY: Catherine Woods 
      was found stabbed to death in November 2005. A talented and ambitious 
      young woman, Catherine moved to New York hoping to sing and dance on 
      Broadway. But her dreams were cut short by a brutal attack that left those 
      in her hometown of Columbus, Ohio shocked. GARDENING: MOTHER’S 
      DAY PLANTS: Looking for a last-minute Mother's Day gift? Steve Orr, 
      contributing Garden editor to Domino magazine, says that plants are 
      the way to go. They last much longer than cut flowers, and look beautiful 
      with very little effort. And, here are plants that can be ordered online 
      and still arrive to Mom on time! Friday morning, Steve Orr will join us 
      with ideas for dressing up inexpensive plants so they look like a million 
      bucks. CSI WEEK: CSI: You can usually expect CSI’s 
      storylines to give you goosebumps or its realistic-looking crime scenes to 
      make your skin crawl. But Thursday night's episode may leave you with 
      something new... a lump in your throat. As our own Julie Chen found 
      out when she visited the set, it was all because of star and executive 
      producer, William Petersen. JANE FONDA ON GEORGIA RULE: 
      After a fifteen year absence from the silver screen, two time Academy 
      Award winner Jane Fonda was welcomed back with open arm in 2005 with the 
      hit comedy Monster-In-Law. Now her many fans are in luck, as they 
      just had to wait two years for her followup, Georgia Rule, which 
      hits theaters Friday. We’ll speak with Fonda about her new film. 
      WITHOUT A TRACE: Analyce Guerra was last seen at 
      approximately on April 23, 2006, at her home in Smyrna, Tennessee. What 
      happened to little Analyce? Friday morning, we’ll take a look at the story 
      behind her bizarre disappearance. JAMESTOWN COMMEMORATION: 
      America is marking its 400th anniversary this weekend. It was in 1607 that 
      104 men and boys landed in Jamestown, Virginia to found America's first 
      permanent English settlement. Our own Russ Mitchell will join us live from 
      Jamestown where he will be speaking with author and historian James Horn. 
      SURVIVOR CASTOFF: SURVIVOR CASTOFF: Stranded in Fiji, the 
      competition heats up for the remaining survivors battling it out for the 
      million-dollar prize. Alex makes a last minute attempt at a power play to 
      split the alliance of six. Is he successful? Who will be voted off the 
      island? Friday morning, we'll have a recap of the new episode and as 
      always, talk to the next castoff about what really went wrong. 
      HENRY WINKLER: The man who epitomized cool as “The Fonz” on 
      Happy Days, has certainly come a long way from his leather jacket 
      and jukebox days. Now an author of a children’s book series, Winkler 
      writes in the voice of his fourth-grade alter ego, Hank Zipzer, who is 
      smart but battling dyslexia. Winkler himself found out about his own 
      learning disabilities as an adult. The newest book is The Curtain Went 
      Up, My Pants Fell Down, in which protagonist Hank tries out for a 
      school play despite the challenge of memorizing lines. It is an 
      inspirational tale – one with lessons of hope and triumph. Friday morning, 
      Henry Winkler will join us with more on his turn as an inspiration to 
      children everywhere. If you would like more information on any of 
      these stories or the broadcast, please click on the following address and 
      e-mail us: earlyshow@cbs.com 



SATURDAY ON 48 HOURS 
      MYSTERY, 9PM/8C Here's a preview of Saturday's 48 
      Hours Mystery, DEATH OF A DREAM from 
      Correspondent, Erin Moriarty: "I have never quite believed 
      the theory that "anyone" is capable of committing murder. With most 
      killers, you usually detect a problem in their childhood or a personality 
      defect that causes that person to choose to take the ultimate action 
      against another human being. But what would lead a young man with no 
      history of violence to do something so out of character? It is just one of 
      the mysteries that surrounds the murder of 21-year-old Catherine Woods. 
      First, some background: Catherine Woods was a stunning and 
      talented young woman, from my hometown of Columbus, Ohio, who moved to New 
      York with hopes of becoming a dancer and singer on Broadway. As the 
      daughter of the well-known director of the Ohio State University Marching 
      Band, Catherine was used to the spotlight and dreamed of her own name in 
      lights along the Great White Way. But, three years later, on November 
      27th, 2005, she was found stabbed to death in her apartment. Initially, 
      police focused on two suspects, neither of which fits the profile of a 
      killer. They are both young, aspiring musicians with no criminal records. 
      Catherine's murder was exceptionally brutal which makes it all the more 
      difficult to believe that either man could have done it and yet, one was 
      arrested, charged and tried for her murder. In this week's program 
      Death of a Dream, we investigate the evidence and follow the trial 
      that ends with a dramatic and surprising verdict. It is a case that will 
      remind you, as so many of our cases do, how a single, senseless act in a 
      moment of passion, can have drastic consequences for so many." - 
      Erin Moriarty (48 Hours Mystery airs Saturday at 
      10pmET/9CT) If you would like more information on any of these 
      stories or the broadcast, please click on the following address and e-mail 
      us at: 48hours@cbsnews.com 



SUNDAY ON 60 
      MINUTES, 7:00PM/6:00PM CT 
MITT ROMNEY – The Republican presidential candidate talks to 
      Mike Wallace about campaign issues including the war in Iraq, his 
      Mormon religion and his changing positions on abortion. 6% 
      - Realtors’ sacrosanct commission rate of 6 percent may be in jeopardy 
      due to emerging online competition from Internet real estate sellers and 
      buyers. Lesley Stahl reports. ALI-- Bob Simon 
      catches up with Iraqi war orphan Ali Abbas, who lost most of his family 
      and his arms to a stray American bomb during the war in Iraq.
